article.title: OGLE-2016-BLG-1190Lb: First Spitzer Bulge Planet Lies Near the Planet/Brown-Dwarf Boundary

multiple_choice_question.text: What do the vertical dashed and solid lines in the figure indicate for the Spitzer observations?
choices: The start and end dates of the observations.
The times of peak magnification for the two observed anomalies.
The subjective and objective selection dates, respectively.
The times when the planet first and last crossed the Einstein ring.

multiple_choice_question.text: What feature of the planetary caustic entrance is particularly well-defined in this figure?
choices: The time of caustic entrance.
The sharpness of the caustic entrance.
The symmetry of the caustic entrance.
The magnitude difference between the peak and baseline.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the blue caustic structure represent compared to the red caustic structure?
choices: The caustic structure as seen from Earth.
The caustic structure at an earlier time.
The caustic structure for a wide-separation companion.
The caustic structure for a higher-mass companion.

multiple_choice_question.text: Why is the blended light in the (V-I, I) panel important for constraining the lens mass?
choices: It provides an independent measurement of the lens-source relative proper motion.
It helps to determine the extinction towards the source star.
It sets an upper limit on the lens flux, which constrains its mass.
It reveals the presence of additional companions to the lens star.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does this figure demonstrate about the orbital motion of the planet?
choices: The orbital motion cannot be determined without data from the planetary caustic.
The planetary caustic position is predicted with high precision even without data from the caustic crossing.
The model does not accurately predict the position of the caustic.
The data from the cusp approach at peak is crucial for determining the orbital motion.

multiple_choice_question.text: What crucial information do the lower panels of the figure provide for distinguishing between the "large parallax" and "small parallax" solutions?
choices: The peak magnification as seen from Kepler.
The shape of the light curve near peak as seen from Kepler.
The predicted light curve for the planetary caustic crossing as seen from Kepler.
The relative positions of the caustics as seen from Kepler and Earth.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main reason for the different Kepler light curve predictions between the (−, +) and (−, −) solutions?
choices: The source passes on opposite sides of the caustic as seen from Kepler.
The source is moving in opposite directions relative to the lens as seen from Kepler.
The Earth and Kepler observations are offset in time differently for the two solutions.
The caustic structure has a different orientation in the Einstein ring for the two solutions.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main conclusion drawn from this figure regarding the parallax solutions?
choices: The "small parallax" models are a good fit to the Kepler K2 data.
The Kepler K2 data do not show the expected spike for the "small parallax" solutions.
The K2 data are consistent with all four parallax models within the uncertainties.
The systematic uncertainty in the Kp magnitude prevents a robust conclusion.

multiple_choice_question.text: What do these figures reveal about the constraints on the microlensing and Kepler parameters?
choices: Both the microlensing and Kepler parameters are tightly constrained.
The microlensing parameters are well-constrained, but the Kepler parameters are not.
The Kepler parameters are well-constrained, but the microlensing parameters are not.
Neither the microlensing nor the Kepler parameters are well-constrained.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the curvature in the green and black trajectories indicate?
choices: The proper motion of the lens star.
The orbital motion of the planet around the host star.
The orbital motion of the Earth and Spitzer around the Sun.
The microlens parallax effect.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the addition of OGLE-2016-BLG-1190Lb suggest about the distribution of Spitzer planets compared to previous events?
choices: Spitzer planets are preferentially located in the Galactic disk.
Spitzer planets are preferentially located in the Galactic bulge.
The distribution of Spitzer planets is consistent with the underlying planet sensitivity.
There is no clear difference in D8.3 between the planetary sample and the underlying population.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does this figure indicate about the sample of Spitzer planets?
choices: The sample is homogenous, with similar host and planet masses.
The sample is diverse, with a wide range of host and planet masses.
The sample shows a clear preference for low-mass planets around low-mass stars.
The sample is dominated by high-mass planets around high-mass stars.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the primary advantage of using D8.3 as a distance indicator for statistical studies of Spitzer microlensing events?
choices: It is more easily measured than DL.
It provides more accurate distance estimates for lenses near the source.
It is symmetric with respect to nearby and distant lenses.
It is less sensitive to the uncertainty in the source distance.
